blocks.text: Hello everyone, my name is Shadil A M
4th-year Computer Science Engineering student at KTU University
GSoC 2025 Contributor with Zendalona
Worked on zMantra – a math learning game for visually impaired students
Project involved accessibility, research, and real users
Visited blind schools and worked closely with real users
Founder of CodeCompass – an open-source student platform
Contact: Click my name in the footer to visit my GitHub (Email, LinkedIn, Twitter)
This talk is based on my personal GSoC experience
GSoC selection varies heavily by organization
There is no guaranteed formula, only strong patterns
Your journey may look different, and that is okay
Source code is publicly available
Anyone can read, modify, and contribute
Built on transparency and collaboration
Learning happens in public
Open source is shared responsibility, not free code
Powers most of the internet (Linux, Apache, Kubernetes)
Drives AI innovation (TensorFlow, PyTorch)
Used by companies you want to work for
Best way to build a real-world portfolio
GSoC is only one entry point into open source
Global open-source program by Google (started in 2005)
Paid, remote, mentor-driven program
12–22 weeks of real project work
Focus on long-term open-source contributors
Not an internship replacement
Not only about coding
Communication matters more than talent
Consistency beats intelligence
January: Mentoring organization applications open
February: Organizations are announced
March: Contributors interact with organizations and discuss ideas
April: Proposal submission period
May: Accepted contributors announced and community bonding begins
June to August: Coding period and evaluations
November: Completion of long-duration projects
Must be at least 18 years old
Open to students and beginner contributors in open source
Cannot apply to the same organization more than two times
90 hours → $750
Actual effort required is much higher than listed hours
I failed GSoC 2024
That failure taught me how GSoC really works
It made me consistent, not desperate
GSoC 2025 happened because of my GSoC 2024 failure
You do not need to be an expert
Basic programming knowledge is enough
Git and GitHub are non-negotiable
Tech stack depends on the organization
Many first-time contributors get selected every year
Organization selection decides everything
Choose based on interest, not just brand value
Check mentor activity and responsiveness
Check number of slots in previous years
You will work with this organization for 3–6 months

title: What to Do After Finding an Organization

blocks.text: Join the organization’s Discord or Slack channels
Engage in mailing lists and GitHub discussions
Read documentation before asking questions
Introduce yourself clearly and share your interests and skills
Help other newcomers and attend community meetings
Clone the repository and run it locally
Fix setup issues if the project does not run
Start with good-first-issues
Make small but meaningful pull requests
Ask for feedback after every pull request
Organizations look for proof that you can finish the project
Accepted pull requests matter
Good communication and regular meetings are important
Clear and feasible proposals are required
They must justify your selection among hundreds of applicants
Chat means interested candidate
Meeting means serious candidate
Prototype means trusted candidate
Silence usually means rejection
Can this student finish the project?
Will they disappear midway?
Do they communicate clearly?
Do we trust this person?
Proposal matters more than the number of pull requests
Follow the organization template strictly
Eight pages are more than enough
Add a prototype or demo link at the top
Mentors should understand it within 30 seconds
A committee of mentors reviews all proposals
Mentors discuss candidates internally
Selection is based on feasibility, trust, and prior interaction
Demonstrated effort matters more than ideas alone
Direct communication with mentors greatly helps
Google Summer of Code official site
Organizations list page and zendalona website
the proposal for my project
zendalona GitHub repository
my code and my documentation

title: My GSoC Project – zMantra (Quick Case Study)

blocks.text: Problem faced
What I built
Major challenges
What mentors valued
What I’d do differently
GSoC has two evaluations: Midterm and Final
Midterm evaluation contributes 45% of the final result
Final evaluation contributes 55% of the final result
Evaluations are based on progress and communication
Consistency and quality of work are critical
Starting during the proposal period
Submitting weak or generic proposals
No communication with mentors
Overconfidence without proof
Outreachy
Summer of Bitcoin
Linux Foundation (LFX) Mentorship
Start before the proposal season
Become a known name in the organization
Meetings are more effective than chats
Prototypes matter more than promises
Evidence matters more than confidence
Contact previous contributors early
Build and share prototypes before the application deadline
Try to get meetings with mentors
Meetings are a strong signal of selection
Show clear proof that you can finish the work
Start early
Be consistent
Communicate clearly
Build evidence
GSoC rewards effort, not luck
